15th June 1905

Sir,

I beg leave to say that our teacher at Kineebetha Indian day school on the Rupert River Indian Reserve is desirous of having something done to make the school house fit for her to live in. I may say the school house is quite large enough to have a partition across, and make a reasonably comfortable room for the teacher to live in. It would take about 270 feet of dressed siding to make the partition which would cost delivered there say about $35.00.

Then if we had about 1000 feet of common lumber to put up a wood shed at the end of the school house it would hold the wood in winter, and would do for a summer kitchen, that would be worth about $18.00 about 20 lbs of nails $1.00
16 oz shingles at $2.75 per thousand say $4.00 and ten dollars to do the work altogether about $38.50

hoping to have permission to have the work done I am Sir

Your obedient servant,
S. Hagan
Indian Agent

The Secretary

Extract from teacher's report on the Serpent River School for the year ending March 31st, 1910.

Prizes should be given at the closing of school for vacation as well as at Christmas.

Mrs. J. H. Mackay,
Teacher,
Outler, Ont.
Ottawa, April 7th, 1910.

Madam,

Referring to your annual report on the Serpent River school the Department would like to know what prizes you would suggest to give to the children at the close of the present term and the probable cost.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Mrs. J. H. MacKay,
Teacher,
Outler, Ont.
Butter P.O. April 5th, 1910
Ontario.

The Honourable.
The Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Sir,

I had the honor to receive your letter of March 3rd No. 157177, in which you inform me that my salary will be increased to $400.00. For which I sincerely thank the Department.

I will use my best efforts with both parents and children to try and secure a more regular attendance...

I remain dear sir,
Your most humble servant,
Jessie H. MacKay.
The Honourable
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

In compliance with your request in your letter of April 15th, I cannot say that I can suggest very wisely, but will just state what I have been in the habit of giving the children when closing the school for Christmas week. I always give candy, nuts, and either popcorn or cakes. But a year ago I decided to just give the candy and other sweets at Christmas and keep the presents until the last day of the June term, as I find it more difficult to have a fairly regular attendance from sugar making until after potato planting than any other term in the year.

Ever since I have taught I have given a little present. Always bought them when I went to Owen Sound for my vacation. I always took the names of the pupils in the register so as to know the number of presents to buy. For the boys I generally got a picture book, a neck tie, or a pocket-handkerchief.
for the girls either hair ribbons, bells, or a fancy string of beads, pocket handkerchief or muslin to make an apron for each. They take better care of a fancy article than of a useful one.

Last summer I bought 15 belts, when taking so many I got them for 15¢ each. Got 7 books for the boys at the same price. The belts and books I still have until the end of this term. I might have given more expensive presents but did not think I could afford to.

I have the honour to be, sir,
your obedient servant,
J. H. MacKay.

Will give the items that I got last for Christmas and June term.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6162, file 427-5, part 1)
October 2nd 1911

The Honourable
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of Sept. 28th, I am pleased to inform you that the school chimney was rebuilt September 30th. I paid the Mason and sent the duplicate accounts to Mr. Hagan the day after.

The chimney had to be taken down to the peak of the roof.

The fence is not put up around the school yet. I heard Mr. Hagan the last time he was here ask the Chief why it wasn't up yet. The chief said the Indians didn't want to help to put it up without being paid for their work. They think especially since they sold butter, that the Department has so much of their money, that they should be paid for all they do for the school or grounds.

I remain dear sir,

Your obedient servant,
Jessie H. MacKay.
Extract from Quarterly Return of the Serpent River Indian Day School for the quarter ended December 31st, 1911.

Original on File 151717-2.

As the Department stated that I might have $8.00 for presents at Christmas and also $5.00 for prizes at the end of the June quarter for the children, I thought perhaps it would be best just to get $2.00 worth of candy, nuts and cakes at Christmas and give the prizes before vacation to try and have the children attend school better in the summer, as they are so fond of playing outside when the weather is nice. So I got $1.00 worth of candy, 50¢ nuts and 50¢ worth of cakes. If the Department is willing I could get a nice little present for each with the $8.00 before the June vacation.

(Sgd.) J.H. McKay,
Teacher.

Extract from remarks on the return of the Serpent River School for the quarter ended June 30th, 1912.

The Department kindly said that I could have $5.00 to buy presents at Christmas and $5.00 at the end of the June quarter.

At Christmas I got just $2.00 of candies, nuts and cakes. Thought it would be best to give the presents just before summer vacation as it is so hard to keep some of them in school in summer. So I got 10 boys caps at 25 cents each at Cutler. Am enclosing receipt. Sent to the R. Simpson Toronto for 3 more caps and 24 yards of ribbon for the girls. As I got nice ribbon there so much cheaper. The 4 yards at 15 cents were for the two best girls, the 20 yards they have not sent me the bill of yet. I will send it when they do. I paid $3.05 to Simpson and $2.50 here. In all $5.55 I paid.

J. H. MacKay,
Teacher.

Dear Sir,

I rec'd your letter on Saturday. I hope you will find the receipt I am sending you correct. The reason I sent to Simpson's Toronto was because I could get ribbons so much better for the same money.

They do not mark paid on their account, but it is of course known one has to send the money before they will send the articles. The Department will understand, at least I hope they will think it all right. The Simpson Co. did not even send the full account—at first I wrote to them for a receipt after I got to Owen Sound.

I have had a better for the last couple of days as they are back from the berry picking.

Yours very respectfully,

J.H. Thacker.

Sir,

I beg leave to say that I was notified that the roof of Kenabuteh Indian School House was in a poor condition and would be better to have a new roof put on. I went down on the spot to better and found the roof in a very poor condition and would recommend a new roof. We have a material here for the roof of buildings called Pariot. I am told by builders that it will last 20 years and I can get at I think for $250 per ton and we will have to pay $4.00 per square for shingles. Kindly let me know if I may have a new roof and if so, what material nice I use. Kenabuteh School is on the Serpent River reserve.

Your obedient servant,
Samuel Hagan
Indian Agent

In answer to your letter of the 17th instant, I am damaging the school house by having a dance there, and in justice to myself, I have been instructed that when I went to the district office to report it, I immediately for this year. Of course went to the school house, found the desks all removed and carried into the teacher's room. The floor was disturbed and scratched by what appeared to be river boats. I found everything in a mess. Had often forbid the Indians using the school house for dancing purposes. They would say the school house was their own and they could do as they pleased with it. I summoned the notorious William Johnson and Louis Breckwood, before me to know by what authority they went into the school house and I made them promise not to do so again but the desks back as they got them scrub the floor and pay the cost of the constable in the matter, and I may say, thus they shook hands with me and thanked me heartily for being so easy with them. I have heard since that they had introduced drink there and sold it. That there were two Indians and a white man drunk. I cannot prove who brought the liquor there, so I dispense it as I have reported, there may be some of the teacher's things stolen but I cannot tell until she comes back. If I have any control or authority over the school house I will show it or we will soon have no house.

MEMORANDUM,

Scheels Branch.

On February 5th, I visited the Serpent River reserve near Cutler.

The house which the Indian Robertson desires to sell for a school is apparently in good repair, having been built about four years ago. It has a hardwood floor and the ceilings and walls are sheeted. It is set on posts. There is a small lean-to at the back suitable for storing wood. Robertson does not desire to rent the house but offers to sell for $450.00. Sufficient land would go with the school to make a reasonable sized playground. There is a wire fence around the lot.

The desks from the old school are stored in a neighboring Indian's house. There are sufficient of these for 24 pupils. There is also a bed and dresser used by the former teacher. The teacher's desk is at present in the church and in this desk are several school books and scribblers.

The Chief was absent hunting but his wife stated that there were 22 children of school age on the reserve.

A teacher could secure excellent boarding accommodation in Cutler which is 1/2 mile distant.

Mr. Agent Hagan reported that the Serpent River school house was burned to the ground on the 5th of November last, but the school furniture and contents of the building were saved.

Extract from Report of Inspector Bennett on the Serpent River Indian Day School. November 17, 1919. Original on 15/17/17.

SCHOOL FURNITURE.

The damper in the stove pipe is broken. It means a school full of smoke and poor fires. The cold weather is almost here and this needs absolute attention.

Teacher.

This teacher pays $30.00 per month and new management is taking over the only boarding house there is and it will mean $32 or $36 per month. At present no hot water can be obtained by boarders unless they go across the road for it. The mill has closed and the best of the population has departed. The previous teachers had a room of their own in the school. It was burnt. The boarding and rooming facilities are poor. Do what you can.

BUILDINGS, etc.

At present this temporary building needs to be banked for the winter. It needs painting. The wood-shed leaks bad. One of the closet doors is off.

An old box desk is the only cupboard to store equipment and books.

Teacher's desk is a table.

Stove pipes need cleaning and burnished before next fall.

OTTAWA, April 28th, 1921.

Sir,

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Serpent River Indian Day School, states that a cupboard is required to store equipment and books, also that a new desk is required for the teacher. At present there is only a table.

He also states the stove pipes need cleaning and polishing before next Fall, a wash basin, drinking cups and looking glass are needed. The windows need cleaning and the floor is in urgent need of scrubbing. He also states the "lean to" and school building need shingling.

I have therefore to request that you will be good enough to have the stove pipes cleaned and polished. You should also purchase a wash basin, two drinking cups and a looking glass. You will also be good enough to have the windows in the building cleaned and the floor scrubbed. As soon as the cleansing above mentioned is completed and purchase of the articles required made, you should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

You should furnish a report as to the shingling required, and state whether, in your opinion, it is absolutely necessary that this work should be done this coming summer. If so, you should furnish an estimate of the cost of the shingles and the labour of having them put on.

An order will be placed for supplying a teacher's desk and cupboard, and you will be further advised regarding the matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Samuel Hagan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.

RECOMMENDATIONS.

1. The present water supply, from a ditch is to be condemned. A well, with a pump, should at once be placed in the school yard or adjoining yard.

2. The school yard should be cleaned of manure and rubbish.

3. There are three buildings at north side of yard, in adjoining lot. They are old half broken down and seem to be of no service, and they are filled with old manure and rubbish, hides, old clothes and bones. These are sources of danger to the health of the school children. They should be torn down at once, the best part of the lumber removed and the debris completely destroyed by fire.

4. There are three closets close to the school fence, in adjoining yards, that are not clean or in a sanitary condition. They should be removed to some distance from the school yard and the pits properly filled up.

5. The door on one of the school closets requires attention so that it will close properly.

6. There are twenty-eight pupils and only eleven double seats and two chairs. More seats are required.
JOHN J. McDERMOTT, M.D.C.M.

OTTAWA, October 19th, 1922.

Sir -

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing the sanitary inspection report of Dr. Moeberratt on the Serpent River Indian Bay School, I beg to say it is noted that the doctor makes certain recommendations regarding the water supply and the school grounds. He recommends that a well with a pump be placed in the school yard as the present water supply, which is obtained from a ditch, is condemned.

I would be pleased if you would state the cost of drilling a well and installing a pump, and also whether you would recommend that this work be carried out.

The doctor further recommends that the three buildings on the north side of the school yard, in the adjoining lot, be torn down, the best part of the lumber removed, the debris destroyed and the site thoroughly cleared up. He also states that the school yard should be cleaned of manure and rubbish, and that there are three closets close to the school fence, in adjoining yards, in a very unsanitary condition, which should be removed to some distance from the school and the pits properly filled up.

I would be pleased if you would endeavour to arrange with the owners of the three old buildings and the closets to have them removed, and you should have the school yard cleaned of all manure and rubbish.

The door on one of the school closets should be repaired, as it will not close properly, at as early a date as possible.

I will be pleased to hear from you regarding the well, and what arrangements you have been able to make regarding the removal of the buildings and the closets referred to by the doctor.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

He states that three require to be repaired, as they are quite shaky, and that some of the desks from the public school need cleaning before being put in the school.

Please arrange to have any repairs required made to the desks already in the school and inform the Department regarding the transferring of any desks from the public school. Please state whether these desks are being transferred without cost and what arrangements have been made, if any, for their transfer. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the cost of any work in repairing the desks at present in the school.

The Inspector also states that the stove pipe needs a damper. You should arrange to have the present damper repaired or a new one supplied. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering any expenditure incurred for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Ottawa, October 25, 1927.

Sir:

An officer of the Department visited the Serpent River Indian Day School on the first instant and the teacher brought to his attention the present condition of the roof. While it is realized that the whole of the roof is in rather bad condition, still, some minor repairs would probably make the building more habitable for the winter. I have to request, therefore, that you will make immediate arrangements to have this roof repaired in the places where it leaks. The expenditure incurred in this regard should be kept as low as possible.

The teacher requested, also, that a ton of coal be secured, in order that she could keep a fire in the school more easily during the night. Please let me know if you consider that this could be arranged and, if so, state the probable cost that would be involved in securing the quantity of coal needed and having it delivered to the Serpent River School.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report having visited the Serpent River Indian School on June 24th and found that the school had been built primarily as a private dwelling place. The lighting system is not what the Department of Education call for as the light should all be on the left side of the school. The outside privies were in very poor condition and dirty. It will be necessary to have two new toilets built. I found that the open pail and common drinking cup were in use. I would recommend a covered water tank with tap at bottom be provided and sanitary drinking cups be secured.

In conversation with the school teacher I was told that your Department intended to build a new school. Would you kindly let me know regarding this.

I also visited the Mississaugi Indian Separate School on June 25th and found that the only ventilation in this school was from the windows raising from the bottom. I also found the open pail and common drinking cup. The windows in the outside privies were broken and it will be necessary to have these replaced with either glass or screening.

The school will have to be properly ventilated with cold air inlets and window baffles which will deflect the draft over the heads of the children.

I will be making a return visit to this school immediately after the holidays and I hope that the necessary improvements will have been made by that time.

Yours truly,

R.B. McCauley
Provincial Sanitary Inspector.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Provincial Sanitary Inspector, reporting on his visit to the Serpent River and Mississauga River Indian Day Schools.

The Department is not prepared to authorize any expense in changing the lighting system at the Serpent River School. However, you should arrange, during the present summer holidays, to have the toilets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good condition. Any repairs required should also be carried out. You may arrange for the purchase of a covered water tank with tap at bottom. It is considered that a tank of from four to six gallons capacity would be satisfactory. You may also purchase the number of enamelled drinking cups necessary for the individual use of the pupils.

Relative to the Mississauga Indian Day School, you may also arrange for the purchase of a covered water tank with tap at bottom for this school and the number of individual enamelled drinking cups required for the pupils' use. You should arrange to have the necessary repairs made to the windows in the closets and to have the toilets themselves thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition.

Please have the water tanks and cups delivered when the schools reopen and the repairs and cleaning of the toilets carried out before the schools reopen. You should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for the above purposes for each of these schools, separately.

Should the Inspector visit these schools after the holidays and make a further report to you, please send same to the Department for attention.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Mar. 2, 1939

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Request for new School on Indian Reserve at Cutler, Ont.

Mr. Thomas Farquhar, M.P., has left with us the attached correspondence addressed to him by the Rev. Father Joseph Barker, Indian Missionary, Spanish, Ont., in which the provision of a new school is strongly urged.

You might ask the Director of Indian Affairs to furnish a full report. Also, let me have a draft letter to Mr. Farquhar, returning the attached correspondence.

Enclosure.

Dr. McGill -

For draft reply as requested.

W.J. Pratt
Private Secretary.
Ottawa,
March 20, 1939.

Dear Mr. Farquhar:

The letters received by you from the Rev. Joseph Barker, S.J., in connection with the proposed new school on the Indian Reserve at Cutler, Ont., have been given careful consideration.

No provision has been made in the 1939-40 estimates for the erection of a new school at this point during the coming year. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch are not convinced that a new school should be established on this Reserve the resources of which seem to be wholly inadequate to meet the needs of the Indian population. Inspector McCookin in a recent report states:

"There are thirty-seven families resident on this Reserve which contains 26,700 acres. These Indians are in very poor circumstances through no fault of their own. The Reserve is little more than a rock pile. The future of these Indians is a problem which will have to be faced sooner or later. In their present surroundings they cannot make a living."

We are communicating with the Indian Agent in an attempt to discover if a better building for school purposes can be secured by the Department. If such a building cannot be secured an attempt will be made to improve the building at present in use.

Yours sincerely,

Thos. Farquhar, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

PP
Ottawa,
March 20, 1939.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I desire to refer to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of March 2 with reference to the letter received from Mr. Thomas Farquhar, M. P., regarding the Serpent River Indian day school on the Indian Reserve at Cutler, Ont.

While this Branch recognizes that a new school is required at this point we have hesitated to recommend its erection due to the reports received from our Inspector. I quote from Mr. McCookin's report dated July 7, 1938:

"Ojibbeways of Lake Huron; population, 147. There are thirty-seven families resident on the Reserve which contains 26,700 acres. These Indians are in very poor circumstances through no fault of their own. The Reserve is little more than a rock pile. It would be impossible for the most diligent and experienced white farmers to make a living on this land. We can never hope to make farmers of these Indians. They have a few acres - 15 or 20 - under cultivation, mostly gardens. They have six horses and two cows, the total stock on the Reserve.

"A few years ago there were twelve lumber mills operating in this section. The lumber business gave the Indians steady work the year round. Today only one mill in Blind River is operating. There is no work of any description for these Indians. They sell a little pulpwood when it is in demand and go berry picking in season. Every family is receiving relief."
"The future of these Indians is a problem which will have to be faced sooner or later. In their present surroundings they cannot make a living.

"Until it is definitely decided what is to be the ultimate future of this Band, I would hesitate recommending the building of a new school or a programme of house building in the meantime."

At the present time the school is being conducted in a rented building and I am writing to the Indian Agent with a view to ascertaining if some better building could be secured. Under the circumstances I feel that this is all that we can do at the present time.

I enclose draft reply which might be sent to Mr. Farquhar.

The correspondence which you forwarded is returned.

Director.

Feb 21/35
Ottawa,
March 22, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The day school on the Serpent River Reserve near Cutler is in bad condition but officials of this Branch are not convinced that a new school should be established on this Reserve owing to the fact that there appears to be no adequate resources for the Indians on the Reserve on which they are located.

On the first occasion on which you visit this Reserve you should make careful inquiries with a view to ascertaining if there is any other more suitable building that could be rented for school purposes. If not you should let me know the approximate amount that would be necessary to put the present building in reasonably good condition. The funds at our disposal are limited but we would be prepared to provide some funds in order to make the building as habitable as possible under the circumstances.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mrs. Farquhar:

Some months ago I called upon you in your home to speak to you of our dire need of a new school on the Indian Reserve at Cutler, Ontario, and I promised to gather the necessary information for you to work upon in your insistent demand before the Department. I am enclosing a map of the Reserve, two copies of the resolution passed in a special council of the Indians at Cutler, and signed by the Chief and his Councillor, a few pictures of the present disgraceful and unhealthy school and a list of the children of school-age and those who will in a few short years have to walk the bloody paths of education.

The present school is certainly a disgrace and is so uninhabitable that there are scarcely ever half of the children on the school register, present at one time. A glimpse at the pictures of the school and especially a few hours spent inside it during any winter day would be a satisfactory explanation to any reasonable person of the ever poorer and poorer attendance.

We trust, Mrs. Farquhar, that as the champion of our truly worthy cause, you will bend every effort to the task of procuring a new school for us before the beginning of the new school term in September 1939.

Yours Sincerely,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter 36-2-5 of March 2nd, I beg to state that I have visited the Serpent River School and was unable to find any other suitable place to rent.

In my opinion, if school is going to be held at Gutler at all, a new one is what is really needed. As far as trying to make any repairs to the present one, it is just throwing away money.

But if, as you say, the present one has to be used, storm windows are needed, tar paper to fix the roof and the teacher's quarters need repairing inside. I would estimate that $150.00 would be sufficient to make any temporary repairs needed.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in which you state that a new school is required to replace the present Serpent River school. As no funds were provided for this purpose in the current year's appropriation it is impossible to provide a new building at the present time.

If the cost of the material exceeds $50.00 you will have to forward full particulars regarding what is required in order that purchase may be made by the Purchasing Agent. Copy sent to Father Barker

Ottawa,
July 29, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Rev. Father Barker visited the Department this week and brought up the question of school accommodation at the Serpent River school.

As you were informed in official letter of May 9 no funds were provided in the current year's appropriation for the erection of a new building this year. The Department has, however, made a special note of the necessity for improving the school accommodation at this point and very careful consideration will be given to the matter when we are preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41.

However, it should be possible to make some improvements to the building so that it will be reasonably habitable for the coming academic year. In official letter of May 9 you were authorized to expend an amount of $150.00 for material and labour. As no accounts have been received it is presumed that you have not yet taken any action in the matter. I should, therefore, appreciate it if you would make immediate arrangements to make the necessary repairs to the Serpent River school on the understanding, of course, that their cost will not exceed the amount mentioned in official letter of May 9.

The building should be well banked and this will have a tendency to make it warmer for the winter.

R.P.G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
If the cost of the material required exceeds $50.00 you will have to forward full particulars regarding what is necessary in order that purchase may be made by the Purchasing Agent. Only Indian labour should be employed to do the work.

I will expect to hear from you in the near future that this matter is receiving your attention.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of July 25th, 36-2-5, I beg to state that I have started the temporary repairs on the Serpent River School.

I am having the foundation repaired, as it was falling apart, and having it well banked for the winter. New tar paper is being put on where necessary. The outside toilets are being put in satisfactory condition. I think that when these repairs are completed, the school will do for this winter, although it is in very poor shape.

The teacher wanted her residence re-decorated, but I think myself, that it would only be a waste of money to do so this year as the building she is occupying is not worth it. I would strongly recommend, if it is at all possible, that a new school and teacher's residence be built next year, as the present ones are in such poor condition.

Yours very truly,

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to the last paragraph of your letter of the 11th ultimo in which you recommend the erection of a new school and teacher's residence on the Serpent River Reserve.

The question of erecting a new school on this Reserve has been considered on several occasions in the past. However, due to the improbability of any improvement in the economic status of these Indians and also due to the conditions confronting us at the present time the Department hesitates to make any heavy expenditure for erecting a new school.

From your letter I understand that the repairs that you have recently made will put the building in a reasonably habitable condition for the coming winter. I am anxious to know if there is any possibility of renting any other building. In speaking to Inspector McGookin he suggested the possibility of securing a building formerly used either as a Church or a hall by the Anglican Church. Would it be possible to rent this building and, if so, do you consider it would be an improvement on the building at present used?

I should appreciate receiving, as soon as possible, your comments regarding the whole situation on this Reserve.

Yours truly,

R.F.G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,
November 17th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter 36-2-5 of September 28th, I beg to state that I have looked over the Anglican church at Cutler which Inspector McGookin suggested might be rented as a school. My opinion is that it would not be suitable for the purpose.

This church is built on a rocky knoll with no room for a playground. On two sides of the building, the rock slopes off very abruptly which would be dangerous for small children. It is also in a very exposed position and I am inclined to believe that large drifts of snow would form around it during the winter.

To put this building in shape for use as a school, it would take a considerable sum. The roof would have to be reshingled, a wood shed and toilets built, the plaster repaired inside, a new chimney and some windows built. Also, a board walk would have to be built for about fifty feet and steps up to the walk. The owners would doubtless make these necessary repairs if they were assured of a long lease. Even if these repairs were made you would still not have a very satisfactory condition as the school would not be on Indian land and the rent would have to be such as would take care of these necessary repairs.

My opinion is that it would be just as well to put up with the present school until such time as the Department feels justified in building a new one.

Yours very truly,

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

MR. McCOOKIN

Please note Indian Agent Laurence's letter of December 1 in connection with the school on the Serpent River Reserve.

From the last paragraph of the Indian Agent's letter of November 17 I consider that he does not understand our reason for delaying the erection of a school on the Serpent River Reserve.

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
June 19, 1940.

Dear Sir:

The Indian Day School on the Serpent River Reserve near Cutler is in bad condition, as you doubtless know. Last year the sum of $150.00 was spent on it fixing the foundation and repairing the leaks in the roof to put it in shape for the winter.

The roof in the teacher's quarters this year needs repairing and the school needs a porch and painting, both inside and outside. The only way of entrance at present is through a lean-to at the back, which is also the woodshed.

I estimate that it would take about $250.00 to make these necessary improvements. By painting the place and adding a porch it would improve the appearance of this school 100% and help to make this school last for a few more years. With the exception of repairing the roof of the teacher's quarters, the rest of this work is not absolutely necessary, but would greatly improve matters if it could be done.

If, due to the serious nature of the times, it is considered inadvisable to make these improvements, at least the repairs to the roof of the teacher's quarters should be made, for which the cost of material and labour would be approximately $40.00.

Yours very truly,

R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

You may, however, expend an amount not exceeding $40.00 in making the necessary repairs to the roof of the teacher's living quarters. It is noted that this amount covers the cost of both material and labour.

August 22, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find list of materials required to build a woodshed, teacher's toilet, and winter porch for the school at Cutler, on the Serpent River Reserve.

The porch is required on account of the new entrance to the School facing the lake instead of through the old woodshed.

The old woodshed had to be pulled down to build the teacher's quarters and most of the wood was so rotten that it could not be used again. The toilet is necessary.

As the teacher's quarters are now being built, and I expect the work to be completed by the middle of next week, would you kindly advise me as soon as possible if it will be in order to purchase the extra material required to complete this work?

Yours very truly,

R.F.G. Laurence

Dear Sir:

Only nine of the fifteen desks in the Serpent River Reserve Indian Day School are fit for use. The present enrolment is twenty-eight, twice as many attending the school as previously. The shortage of desks is very noticeable. The children are too crowded and many of the desks too small for a number of the children.

To remedy this situation, six double or twelve single desks for Grades 5, 6 and 7 are required.

If the purchase of desks is approved, it may be possible to secure a number of second-hand ones at a reasonable cost from the Public School at Sprague, as I understand the attendance at that school has been reduced considerably and they have some school desks for sale.

Will you kindly advise if these desks can be supplied?

Dear Doctor:

I am enclosing a copy of a communication recently received.
I shall be glad to have any information you care to give with
respect to the matter complained of.

Yours very truly,

(J.T. Phair, M.B., D.P.H.)
Chief Medical Officer of Health

JTP:MI
The Dept. of Health,
Toronto

Dear Sirs:

I had the closest source of water tested recently and the water was "D". I sent word of this down to the Department of Indian affairs along with some other remarks on attendance and am told I had better look for another job. Can you tell me who looks after the prevention of communicable diseases on a Reserve? We've had chicken pox, skin diseases and all sorts of things. To cap the climax just after that terrible storm when our waterholes were so far under that we had to melt snow a mother came in a great dither because her child said I was making nasty remarks about people. I thought the youngster just worn out with the struggle for existence but today testing her hearing I find her totally deaf in one ear. These remarks caused her father the Chief to complain. He is not particularly interested in a pure source of water though takes excellent precautions against any unsterilized draught but I still have the interest of the children at heart. Exposure of this class to typhoid might infect a big military camp if any of the visiting men-at-arms might commit the indiscretion of drinking water. I assure you they would do so only if suffering great pangs of thirst as they are all carefully instructed to take good care of themselves.

Better stuff is plentiful.
It it is twentieth century wisdom to confine my teaching of these children to assuring them that their Angel Guardian watches over them from above I hope the Department of Health give me that statement in writing. I thought they ought to have a supply of good drinking water. If you cannot take any step in the matter would you do me the favour of sending this letter on to the Medical Branch of the Indian Affairs in Ottawa? We are close to white towns, these people travel and our Doctor is a very much overworked man. A person set at leisure like myself is the only one who can kick about things. We need only to see the Gestapo drive up take these children off to be gassed in the interest of sanitation and the troops can lay down their arms. Germany is winning as long as we can not even ask for clean drinking water.

Yours truly,

Mrs. Florene Prud'homme

Teacher at the Indian Day School,

Cutler, Ontario.

EX'D A

Dear Sir:

I enclose, for your information, a copy of a letter which the teacher of the Serpent River Indian Day School recently forwarded to the Department of Health at Toronto. We do not appear to have received the communication to which the teacher refers. Certainly we did not suggest to her that she give up duties because of any complaints she might have made regarding conditions. Our reason for writing to her recently suggesting that we could not retain her services for the coming academic year was due to the report we had received to the effect that the Indians were not satisfied with her services and, as a consequence, were not sending their children to school.

I should appreciate your investigating her complaints at the earliest possible date and submitting a complete report.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Dear Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 2nd, 36-2-5, enclosing copy of a letter which the teacher of the Serpent River Reserve Indian Day School forwarded to the Department of Health at Toronto.

I have investigated her complaints about the closest source of water and had this water tested by the Department of Health, Sault Ste. Marie, and they report that this water is now "A". The previous bad report on this water was very likely due to the surface water running into the creek this Spring.

The water that has always been used for drinking at this school is not the creek close to the school but one about 300 yards East of the school at the old school house. I had this water tested as well and it was found to be "A" also.

I asked Mrs. Prudhomme what her complaints were about the water and the only complaints she had were that the children drank the water out of the creek she had received a bad report on, after she had told them not to. During the severe storm this winter she used this water for one day only for drinking but only after she had boiled it.

The Chief stated that he had heard no complaints about the water and knew nothing of the matter.

With regard to that part of her letter which reads as follows:

"Can you tell me who looks after the prevention of communicable diseases on a Reserve? We've had chicken pox, skin diseases, and all sorts of things".
Dr. Hamill states that he had one case of chickenpox and did not hear of any more although he has been in the school on various occasions. He also states that he was not aware of any great outbreak of skin disease, or all sorts of things, whatever that may mean. Some of the children may have had impetigo, which had been prevalent in this section last winter, even in the town schools. The doctor knew of some cases on the Mississauga Reserve but not on the Serpent River Reserve. If Mrs. Prudhomme knew of any such cases she failed to report same to the doctor when he visited the school.

Yours very truly,

R.P.G. Laurence

Dear Sir:

As you doubtless know from previous correspondence, the Indian Day School on the Serpent River Reserve at Cutler is in a very poor condition and presents an unsightly appearance.

Last year, a lean-to of two rooms was attached to the rear of the school for the teacher's quarters. This addition was not painted and it should be painted now along with the rest of the school. The windows in the school room are of different sizes and are ready to fall out of the casings. New casings should be made for them all. The outside siding has sprung in many places and new siding should be put in to replace the rotten boards.

If these, and a few other minor repairs were made and the school painted, it would improve the school's appearance 100% and help to make the building last until such time as the Department feel they are in a position to build a new school.

In last year's estimates, I requested $200.00 for improvements to this school.

Kindly advise me if you think it possible to make any of these necessary improvements this summer.

Yours very truly,

Enclosed herewith please find requisitions covering school material for the Serpent River R. C. Indian Day School requesting, among other things, 33 single school desks for the school room and a pump and sink for the school house.

The school desks are badly needed as the double desks in use at present are, as Mrs. Ellis states, falling apart. They are also too small for the children and crowd them together, which is very uncomfortable for them.

If at all possible, these single desks should be supplied, as it is hard for the teacher to get the best out of the children if they are not comfortably seated.

The attendance at this school has been the best this year that I have seen.

The pump and sink requested are also necessary, as water has to be carried a long way for this school. Previously, the teacher did not live in the school, so a pump was not necessary, but now that the teacher resides at the school, one is required. The approximate cost for material and labour to instal pump, sink, and make cesspool would be $50.00.

RPGI/MY

Your letter 36-2-5, March 13, 1943 approved an expenditure of $50.00 to obtain a sink, pump, sufficient pipe and to pay for the labour in driving a well point in the Serpent River School Residence to obtain water for the school. This has been done, the point driven 20 ft., but without results.

If a further attempt to obtain water for this school is to be made a deep well pump is required, which will cost about $25.00 and the well point driven to about 30 or 35 ft. If water in sufficient quantity is not then obtained a well will have to be dug. As closely as I can estimate the approximate cost of digging this well will be in the neighbourhood of $125.00 including the deep well pump. The original cistern pump cost $5.00

Mrs. Margaret Ellis, the teacher of this school insists that she be supplied with water.

Kindly advise me if it will be in order to proceed with this work.

R. P. G. Laurence,

The Indian Day School at Cutler on the Serpent River Reserve require about 27 single desks as the present double desks in this school are old and broken and no longer suitable for the school.

The Public school at Spragge about 10 miles from Cutler has closed one room in the school on account of lack of pupils. I can obtain from this school 6 No. 2 desks and 8 No. 3 desks at a cost of $5.00 each. These desks are all good strong desks. The cost of transportation would be approximately $10.00.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Many of the desks at the Serpent River Indian Day School, in the Sault Ste. Marie Agency, are old and broken and no longer suitable.

The public school located near our Indian school has recently closed, owing to lack of pupils, and the Agent states that he can obtain 6 No. 2 desks and 8 No. 3 desks at a cost of $5.00 each. He further states that all these desks are in good condition. In addition to the cost of the desks there would be an expenditure of approximately $10.00 for transportation. I feel that this would be an economical purchase and would appreciate having your authority.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Many of the desks at the Serpent River Indian Day School, in the Sault Ste. Marie Agency, are old and broken and no longer suitable.

The public school located near our Indian school has recently closed, owing to lack of pupils, and the Agent states that he can obtain 6 No. 2 desks and 8 No. 3 desks at a cost of $5.00 each. Memorandum:

MR. HOEY.

On November 30 I gave you a draft of the Estimates for "Indian Education" for the fiscal year 1946-47. Under the heading "Structures and Parts - New Construction" there was included a request for certain day schools at a total estimated cost of $590,000.00.

On his return to the office this week from an inspection trip, Mr. Arnell brought to my attention the situation at Serpent River Reserve, located near Cutler, Ont. - Electoral District of Algoma East.

Several years ago the school was destroyed by fire and since that time we have been using a former Indian house as a school. This building has now reached a stage where it is practically impossible to repair it. There are approximately 35 children of school age and Mr. Arnell strongly recommends that provision be made in the Appropriation for the fiscal year 1946-47 for a combined school and teacher's residence on this reserve.

This would involve an additional amount of $8,000.00. I would appreciate having your authority to include this with the other proposed new schools.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

March 13th, 1946.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

On my last visit to the Serpent River Indian Day School there were 32 children attending same. There are 35 children on the school roll.

The size of the school room is 32 feet long by 15 feet wide and 8 feet high. This is a very unhealthy and unsatisfactory condition. The pupils are crowded too closely together to be able to work in comfort. In the cold weather when the stove is going the children near the stove are too warm and this tends to give them colds.

The matter of a new school for this Reserve has been under consideration for years. I strongly recommend that something be done in this connection as soon as possible.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

RFGL/ewe
Ottawa, March 15, 1946.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the attendance at the Serpent River Indian Day School.

Owing to the present program to give priority to the building of houses, it will not be possible for us to erect a new school on the Serpent River Reserve during the summer of 1946. We had hoped to do so, but owing to circumstances beyond our control it will not be possible.

Is there any residence or other building on the reserve, larger than the present building, that could be rented for a year or so? If so, you might let me know at what cost it could be rented and what expenditure, if any, would be required to renovate it for school purposes. If my suggestion is feasible, it is the only manner in which we can provide increased accommodation on this reserve before 1947, or it might even be later.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Erection of Two Day Schools
in Sault Ste. Marie Agency -

It is our intention to begin our building programme with the erection of standard one-room day schools with attached teacherages at the following points:

(a) Serpent River

This will replace a day school which was burned some years ago. We are at present operating in a rented house. It is one quarter mile from the Cutler railway station on the Sudbury-Soo branch of the C. P. R.

(b) Mississauga

This will replace a day school which was burned two years ago. We are at present operating in a rented church. It is three miles from the Blind River railway station on the above line.

As these two places are but 25 miles apart on the railway line, it was felt that they would provide a good beginning for school construction in 1947-48.

Therefore, would you now prepare the plans and specifications for these buildings, as previously discussed.

Our Educational Survey officer is ready to proceed to the site of these schools with one of your officials when you are ready to survey the actual location of the buildings.

We have sufficient funds available to cover incidental expenses involved in the above preparatory work.

Director.

Memorandum

Re: One Room Day School & Teachers' Quarters - Serpent River Reserve and Mississauga Reserve Sault Ste Marie Indian Agency, Ontario.

Reference your marginal note of 26th February on letter from the Director of Indian Affairs dated February 24, in which the latter requested that this Service make an inspection of the two above noted sites.

In accordance with instructions, therefore, our Engineer Mr. Rankin, proceeded to Spanish, Ont., on the morning of April 21st, where he met Mr. Doucet, Educational Survey Officer and Mr. Lawrence, Indian Agent.

An inspection of the Serpent River Site was made and two test pits excavated. A location on the site was found to be suitable and measurements of the area were taken. The accompanying Plan, Index No. 835, Sheet 1, indicates the extent of the site chosen. An alternative site, seven-tenths of a mile closer to Cutler was inspected, and while the soil conditions and drainage were suitable, the location would not be as convenient for 29 of the 34 pupils registered as that decided upon.

Our Engineer then proceeded to the Mississauga River Reserve, where investigation of that site proved same to be acceptable in all respects. Measurements were taken and are shown on Plan, Index No. 836, Sheet 1. Photographs of both sites are attached.

Our Engineer reports that potable water from wells should be easily available and drainage from the proposed schools ought to cause no difficulty.

Our officer returned to Ottawa the morning of April 23rd.

(Sgd.) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Serpent River Indian Day School.

One of the most urgent of our building requirements for day schools in 1948-49 is the erection of a one-room school on the Serpent River Indian Reserve, near Massey, Ontario. At the present time classes are being conducted in a dilapidated old store which is very badly overcrowded. There are some 36 children crowded into a very narrow space and conditions are most unsanitary. The teacher's quarters are minute in size and most inadequate in every other respect.

Our Superintendent of Education recently inspected this school and reports that we are fortunate to have a teacher who will put up with these conditions.

Last year we included a sum for the construction of a new school in our estimates but were unable to interest a contractor in this work. Mr. Indian Agent Laurence was successful in getting a contractor interested in a school at Mississauga, near Blind River but could not interest a contractor for Serpent River.

Therefore, it would be appreciated if we could be advised of any good carpenter who would undertake the construction of this school on a day labour or labour contract basis. We would provide the necessary materials through the Departmental Purchasing Agent as we have a complete list of all materials required for the construction of this standard school building. We have found that this system of erecting schools has worked very well elsewhere and are quite willing to erect the Serpent River School on the same basis.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Indian Day School with Teacher's Quarters, Serpent River Reserve, Sault Ste Marie Indian Agency, Ontario.

In reply to your notation of July 21st on Mr. Hoey's memorandum dated July 19th last, with which were forwarded tenders from Geo.V. Hannah of Sault Ste Marie, and J.A. Bernier of Spanish, Ontario, with relevant correspondence from Superintendent Lawrence, you are advised as follows:

(a) The tender of Geo.V. Hannah, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Mr. Hannah under date of July 9th, submitted an estimate of $18,500.00 and indicated he would accept a fixed fee of $1,290.00. This fixed fee is approximately 6%. For this fixed fee, Mr. Hannah would supply all labour and material.

Superintendent Lawrence took further action in obtaining a second quotation by telephone from this contractor, which was for supplying labour only at a lump sum for labour, and a fixed fee for his own services, or $1,000.00. Under this arrangement, materials would be government issue, supplied and accounted for, by the Department.

Comment:

There is no justification for the expenditure of the amount of $18,500.00 for labour and materials on the one-roomed school with teacher's quarters. The rate of his fixed fee is reasonable.

Provided Mr. Hannah is equipped as a contractor, and could submit an estimate of the cost of labour for approval, it would be satisfactory to enter into an agreement with him at a fixed fee of $1,000.00, which works out at about $12.00 per day for a three months job.

(b) The tender of J.Arthur Bernier, Spanish, Ontario.

Mr. Bernier submitted a tender under date of June 29th for a lump sum of $19,000.00. He states that this price is based on cost plus 15% including payment for carpenters and other tradesmen at current rates.

Under date of July 13th, Mr. Bernier submitted an alternative tender, wherein he estimates the cost of the building at $19,000.00, and for construction he would accept a fixed fee of $2,100.00.

G.E.B. Sinclair, Esq.,
Acting Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Comment:

The estimated cost is excessive, and the rate of Mr. Bernier's fixed fee is high, being slightly above 11% of the estimated cost. It is not considered to be in the interest of the Department, to take any further action with Mr. Bernier.

Only Mr. Hoey's covering letter bearing your notation has been detached for our records, the other correspondence being attached hereto, for return to the Indian Affairs Branch as requested.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

Serpent River Indian Day School,
Sault Ste. Marie Agency.

This is one of our most dilapidated schools and we have been trying for two years to interest a contractor in erecting a new one. The school at present is operated in an old store building and the teacher is living in the warehouse at the back.

In spite of all our efforts, we have not been able to get a tender submitted at a reasonable price. The previous two tenders received were submitted to the Lands and Development Services Branch and it was felt that both these estimates were high. Mr. George V. Hannah of Sault Ste. Marie submitted an estimate of $18,500, and Mr. Bernier of Spanish, Ontario, submitted a lump sum tender of $19,000. Mr. Hannah stated that the only other way he would be interested in the construction of the school, would be an estimated cost of labour with a fixed fee of $1000, for himself provided he could start the foundation within two weeks time.

Mr. Indian Superintendent Laurence has now been able to obtain a third tender and this is submitted herewith for your consideration. It has been submitted to Lands and Development Services branch for their advice and their comment is as follows:

"With reference to your marginal notation dated August 30th, on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you of the 25th ultimo, we have examined the composite tender submitted to Indian Superintendent Laurence, and consider the interests of the Department would be best advanced by arranging with Emile Marier of Massey, Ontario, to..."
furnish his own services and supervise construction for a lump sum fee of One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.00).

Under this arrangement labour and materials would be Government issue, chargeable directly to the Indian Affairs Branch.

I would recommend that you approve the erection of this school under the supervision of Emile Marier, whom our Superintendent has recommended as being reliable, for a lump sum fee of $1,000.00. Most of the other labour would be Indian and the Department would buy through our Purchasing Agent all materials. It is felt that in this way we can erect the school at a much more reasonable rate than by the contract prices mentioned above.

September 14, 1948.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Supt. Indian Agency, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,

Serpent River Indian Day School.

Today I have sent you the following telegram:

"RE SERPENT RIVER DAY SCHOOL MINISTERIAL APPROVAL
OBTAINED ACCEPTANCE TENDER EMILE MARIER SUPERVISE
CONSTRUCTION SCHOOL FOR ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS STOP
WILL FORWARD LETTER AND CONTRACT"

As indicated above, the Department has accepted the tender of Emile Marier to supervise the construction of the standard one-room day school and attached teacher's residence on the Serpent River Reserve for the sum of $1,000. I am forwarding you under separate cover three additional sets of blueprints and specifications for use by Mr. Marier and yourself.

As advised you by telegram, it is our intention to have arrangements made for the shipping of surplus cement from the Lakeview Indian Day School, West Bay Reserve, Manitoulin Island to Cutler for use in the construction of this new school.

I have also issued instructions to Mr. H.P. Ruddy to forward to you the following re-inforcing materials available at the Golden Lake Agency:

(1) 873 lineal feet Re-inforcing rods
(2) 1300 square feet Re-inforcing mesh

Authority has being granted for the local purchase by you of stone, sand, tiles and basement window frames.

This means that as soon as the cement and re-inforcing materials arrive, you can immediately take steps
to begin the erection of the school.

Payment of Wages:

I have requested our Chief Treasury Officer to forward you an accountable advance of $5000. to pay Mr. Marier and the local day labour which will be required for the construction of this school. This advance can be accounted for in the usual manner, by a submission of day labour returns. We will have a Contract prepared for signature by Mr. Marier in which we will indicate how payments can be made to him.

Storage Shed:

You are authorized to make local purchase of the lumber and materials listed in your letter of September 8 as being required for the erection of a small storage shed.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

December 23rd, 1948

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

Re: NEW SERPENT RIVER R.C. SCHOOL,

Miss E.M. Robicheau, teacher at the above named school, has requested that a garage be built at this new school, also that a flagpole be erected and a pulley clothesline be put up and that a medicine cabinet be built somewhere in the school.

With reference to the garage, there will be enough lumber left over to build one for her car. The only new material required would be roofing paper and insul brick for the siding.

I would recommend that while we have the carpenters there, a garage be built for this school. It would not add much to the cost and now a days it is more or less a necessity.

R.F.G. Laurence
Superintendent Indian Agency
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.
6th January, 1949.

With reference to your Voucher No. 1552, it is noted that you gave your authority on Purchasing Order No. 35588.

Please note that the authority of a Purchasing Order extends only to the items specifically listed on the Purchasing Order, and at the prices quoted.

Presumably, these window frames were additional to what had already been supplied, and if so, you should advise us to that effect so that we can apply for another Purchasing Order.

Bernard F. Neary,

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The new Serpent River Indian Day School is now completed with the exception of a few minor details such as having two or three loads of gravel around the playground, also a small cement slab in front of each of the entrance steps, the placing of roofing paper on the garage, and cleaning out the drain.

The approximate amount required for labour to complete the above will be $300.00.

I have given instructions to have this work done as soon as possible.

As the unexpended balance of the money forwarded last fiscal year to pay for labour on this work was returned to the Department on March 31st, it would be appreciated if an accountable advance of $300.00 could be forwarded as soon as possible to pay the balance of wages.

Trusting this arrangement meets with your approval.

R. P. G. Laurence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

However, we will forward you an accountable advance of $300.00 from the appropriation provided for repairs and improvements, and when you are forwarding the Credit Voucher you should word it in that manner. The above advance will reach you about the end of the month.

Ottawa, August 12, 1922.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, informing the Department that you can obtain the house of Mrs. Blue Sky for the purpose of a teacher's residence in connection with the Serpent River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the rental of this house until the end of June, next. The Department considers that the sum mentioned by you, viz.: $7.00 per month, would be a fair amount to pay as rent for the house. It should be engaged from September first, next.

It is noted that this house contains 2 stoves, chairs, etc. You should arrange to have the house thoroughly scrubbed and cleaned and, if any other furnishings are required, you will kindly forward a list of them. Only articles absolutely necessary will be supplied.

Will you be good enough to attend to this matter promptly, in order that the house will be ready when the school re-opens on or about September 5th, next. It would be well for you to obtain a lease from Mrs. Blue Sky for the rental of this house at the above rate, from September first to June 30th, 1923.

Dear Sir,

Since my return to Cutler I boarded at the hotel thirty-one days, awaiting some furniture. Then I came out to live in this house the department rented. I remained nine days and was obliged to return.

The store agent Rathen sent here is too small.
It holds eighteen inch (long) wood, and there isn't any that length here, besides it is too small to supply heat enough in cold weather.

I had to cook my meals on a heater, which made it very awkward for me.

The house has no foundation apart from the corners, and is a very cold shack with plenty of bed bugs. I could not sleep at night and had to leave.

There is no water fit for use within one...
half mile, as Mr. Allen
forbid us to use the
water from the ditch,
which is almost dry.

I am very sorry
you put some expense
in this house, and
I am quite willing
to finish my term
from the hotel at the
same time, if you
see fit to engage
another teacher. I shall
be willing to resign
could not think of
living in this house
alone at night. There
are too many drunkards
on the road shouting
and swearing.
Awaiting a reply
from you in the near future,
&c.,
Respectfully Yours,
Eva MacAndrews.
Ottawa, Oct. 27, 1922.

Madam:

I have yours of the 23rd instant, informing the Department of unsatisfactory conditions at the Teacher's Residence at the Serpent River Indian Day School. I have noted that you are willing to complete the term for which you were engaged, but that you will live at the hotel in Cutler.

In reply I beg to state that the Department has learned, with regret, of the difficulties which you have had to face, and I wish to thank you for carrying on your duties without interruption, in spite of unpleasant experiences. I am writing Mr. Agent Rothera, explaining in detail the situation. We will endeavour to satisfactorily dispose of the equipment which we placed in the teacher's residence.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Miss Eva McAndrew,
Teacher,
Serpent River Indian Day School,
Cutler, Ont.
Ottawa, Oct. 27, 1922.

Sir:

I have to inform you that Miss McAndrew, Teacher of the Serpent River Indian Day School, finds it impossible to live in the teacher's residence and is again boarding in the town of Cutler. Miss McAndrew reports the presence of bed bugs in this rented house; claims that the stove is too small for heating purposes; that the house has no foundation and is very cold; that there is no water fit to drink within one-half mile; and that there are too many rowdy characters around for her to remain alone at night.

Will you proceed to Cutler as soon as convenient, and if Miss McAndrew is still of the opinion that it is impossible to live in this rented home, you should try to cancel the lease and make the best disposal possible of the residence equipment which we have lately purchased. If the stove and any other articles can be returned, you should make arrangements in this connection. The accounts will in the meantime be kept on file, unpaid, until we receive your report following your visit to the Serpent River Indian Day School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

C. F. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Sir,

In reply to letter of Oct 27, I am glad to learn the teacher at Kamschatka school near Fort River Band being unable to live in the house, has decided that I received a letter from her stating she had gone back to the trading house. I would tell me the reason why she saw me. I went down next day to report once again your letter.

The store I got was a small cold store, the same as at Kamschatka. I found a bed, a table, a wood stove which I consider large enough for any dwelling. The house is situated away from the road, maybe she is nervous being alone. Have made arrangements with myself to take care of the store, also with Mr. Sage to take care of the bed, spring mattress, a little bed, chairs, if I am unable to procure with the other articles that have been bought here. Maybe there could be used some of the other articles.

I wrote to Mrs. McLean who is coming after Christmas to tell her that the house would not be rented after Oct 31st telling her the reason.

That it is infected with bedbugs.

I shall report just as soon as I have delivered the goods back and in credit slips over what goods were returned.

Your obedient servant,

E. Rotheram

Sir:

In reply I beg to say that the Department will allow rental at the rate of $6 per month to June 30, 1925. This will be the full period for which this cottage will be required. You may arrange for the purchase of the following supplies to fit up this cottage to make it comfortable for the teacher's use, viz: a stove, bed and bedding, table, a small quantity of dishes and kitchen utensils. It is not intended that any expensive articles be supplied. The department will expect you to obtain the furnishings required at the lowest possible cost competitive prices if possible being obtained. Please arrange for the rental of this cottage and the purchase of the furnishings required at as early a date as possible. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred. It might be well to obtain a brief agreement in writing signed by the Indian owner of the cottage covering the rental of same for a period of 6 months from the 1st instant at $6 per month. Any articles which you have on hand should be used in furnishing the cottage.

The question of providing permanent living quarters for a teacher in connection with this school should receive your attention. Please report whether it would be possible to build an addition to the school building which would provide the accommodation required, also whether you could arrange for the purchase of the material required and the fitting and oversight of the labour. If you consider it would be inadvisable to erect an addition to the present school building, please state the cost of fitting up a suitable house near the school. The Department will expect you to give this matter your consideration and furnish a full report early next spring as to what you would advise be done in order to provide permanent living accommodation for a teacher at this school.

Sir:

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, has forwarded a communication which he received from you relative to the erection of a combined school building and teacher's residence on the Serpent River Indian Reserve. Previous correspondence has been had with you regarding the question of building an addition to the present school building to provide living quarters for the teacher. The funds at our disposal this present fiscal year are limited, and it will hardly be possible to consider the erection of a new school with living accommodation for a teacher. Owing to the fact that the mills have closed at Cutler, where a number of Indians formerly obtained employment, the question arises as to whether there will be any likelihood of them removing from Serpent River to other Reserves in the near future to obtain employment. I shall be pleased if you will state your views regarding this, as it would not be advisable, if there is any likelihood of the Indians leaving Serpent River, to undertake the expense of providing a new school building, especially as it is considered that the present classroom facilities should be satisfactory for the purpose.

Regarding the question of the erection of an addition to the present school building, the Department considers that it might be possible to rent a house near the school that could be used as a teacher's residence. If this could be done, it would save the expense at the present time of building an addition to the school. It is necessary that all funds at our disposal this year be used as economically as possible, and if a house could be rented for a few years, it would save considerable expense in building. The Department would like you to visit Serpent River at your early convenience, ascertain if a house is available, and also whether the Indians intend to reside permanently on the Reserve, and inform the Department fully as to your opinion in the matter, having in view the most economical arrangement possible to provide accommodation for the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, May 5th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from Mr. Agent Rothera, Thessalon, relative to the erection of a new school building and teacher's residence on the Serpent River Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that as you are, no doubt, aware the building at present used as a classroom was purchased from an Indian in 1919, and while it may not be entirely suitable for classroom purposes, the Department feels that, owing to the situation at this point due to the closing of the mills at Cutler, where a number of the Indians obtained employment, it may be only a question of time until a number remove from the Reserve, having to go elsewhere to look for employment. Besides, our funds this year are extremely limited, and it will not be possible to provide the money required in putting up a new school building. The Indian band have no funds which could be used for the purpose.

We are again taking this matter up with Mr. Rothera, and requesting him to state his opinion as to whether there is any likelihood of the Indians leaving this Reserve in the near future, and also whether it would not be possible to make arrangements for living accommodation for a teacher by the rental of a house that could be used for the purpose. Failing this, we might be prepared to erect a small addition to the present school building. When we have full information regarding the situation at this point, every consideration will be given to providing comfortable quarters for a teacher.

The communication which you received from Mr. Rothera is returned herewith as requested.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, September 14, 1929.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from the teacher of the Serpent River Indian Day School for bedding, furnishings, cooking utensils and a range for the use of the teacher's residence.

In this connection, I have to say that when this residence was first furnished, and at different times since then, a considerable amount of furnishings, dishes, etc., were supplied. The Department will, however, approve of your arranging for the purchase, to the best advantage, of the following: 1 mattress, 6'x3'; 1 bed spread; 1 comforter; 1 pair flannelette blankets. The above bedding, while serviceable, should be as inexpensive as possible. You may also purchase 1 wash boiler; 1 pair towels; 1 dish towels; 1 teapot; inexpensive curtain material for 6 windows; 6 curtain rods; also a few cooking utensils, such as pans and dishes. Please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the above purchases.

Relative to the linoleum; cupboard; folding couch; rocking chair; rug for bedroom and a new range, I have to request that you will forward the cost of these supplies, also state the necessity for same. You should state the quantity of linoleum required, and the purpose for which it is required, also particulars as to the rug for the bedroom. You should also state the need of supplying a folding couch and rocking chair. Particulars should also be given regarding the cupboard, the purpose for which it is required and the cost, also if you recommend same, whether it could not be built locally, or would have to be purchased.

Relative to the request of the teacher to be supplied with a large range, I would point out that a stove at a cost of $30 was supplied in November, 1928. You should report as to the necessity of providing this large range, as it is thought the amount of cooking the teacher would require to perform could be carried out on the stove which has been supplied.

In forwarding requests of this nature in future, you should give information as to the necessity and the cost of the various items asked for, as it is necessary that your recommendation be received before authority can be given to make the purchase.

When we have a reply giving the information asked for regarding the above items, further consideration will be given as to whether they can be authorized or not.

Your obedient servant,

C. Rothera, Esq.,

The Deputy Superintendent General,

On March 5, 1907, Mr. Superintendent Macdonald was informed that the services of Miss McLellan, the teacher of the Shawanaga school, would not be required after June 30, of that year. These instructions were issued in view of the unfavourable reports received concerning this school.

In January, of 1907, the Superintendent informed the Department that Miss McLellan was well up in years and had little or no willing manner with the children and that there was a strong feeling among the parents to let her be released from the school at the Easter holidays. He gave it as his opinion that a younger person would succeed in securing a greater number of pupils. Mr. Public School Inspector Grant in his remarks on this teacher said that she was not at all suitable for a school of this kind. During the fifteen months she had charge of it, it had run down and was in a bad condition. In a later report he says that the change of teacher was very necessary and a proper step.

On the strength of these reports there was nothing for the Department to do but dispense with her services.

Ottawa, September 3, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

A teacher is required for the Shawanaga school and on the 11th ult. Mr. Supt. Macdonald, of Parry Sound, forwarded an application from Mr. W.A. Elias for the position at a salary of $400 a year. Mr. Macdonald said that he has known Elias personally for many years and found him to be a painstaking teacher and an exemplary man and has no doubt that, if he was stationed at Shawanaga, his influence would be much to the benefit of the band as an educational and spiritual adviser, and he would recommend his engagement in preference to many of the young female teachers that are looking for such a school.

Mr. Macdonald was asked what qualifications Elias had that would command such a salary. He has now forwarded a letter from Elias, in which he describes the work he has been engaged in for the last thirty years, together with a number of testimonials from the Methodist Conference and others, the latest one being dated the 21st August from Mr. George E. Smith, Collector of Customs at Southampton, who certified that he has been acquainted with Elias for the last thirty years and
and has always found him an honourable man, sober, industrious and quite reliable for any position he may be given. Mr. Elias although an Indian is an educated man and an ordained minister of the Methodist Church and has had previous experience in Indian school work.

If this were all the Department knew about Elias I would have no hesitation in recommending his engagement, but upon looking up his antecedents as an Indian I find that the Department refused to transfer him from the Chippewa band of Walpole Island to the Saugeron band on March 26, last, in view of the explanatory letter of Mr. Agent Scoffield referring to the resolution asking for Elias's transfer. Several of the councillors in speaking against his adoption made very damaging statements against Elias. Whether they were actuated by jealousy or not I cannot say, but the Department took the view that he was not a desirable man to adopt.

It is desirable that the school should be opened at once and it is for the Department to say whether it will engage Elias or not. It would be a difficult matter now to secure a qualified teacher and Elias in his letter to Mr. Macdonald is willing to take the place temporarily and be retained on his merits or dismissed on his demerits.
