Sir,

With reference to our teacher Mr. Elias, we beg to inform the Dept. of Indian Affairs that the work as taught done by Mr. Elias has failed to satisfy us in many respects, namely:

1st. The method he uses as made known to our common sense is high school method which method he has used and that we know can not be applied to Public Schools in order to assure success. We know that the children are not making satisfactory progress and have not made any during the past term.

2nd. Not teaching the full time each day, we have known him to dismiss the children at 15 and sometimes before 4 o'clock then goes over to the station.

3rd. Leaving the school for week or more without our knowledge and thereby being absent when the
Public School Inspector was here therefore we have no knowledge of his progress made towards the school.

We laid these complaints before our Agent Mr. McDonald through correspondence and when he was up here on pay-day July 14th he frankly told us that he would not forward them to the Indian Dept and this what leads us to write direct to the Indians Dept as we mean what we are about and we believe to be for our interest even more for our children and we desire the Dept of Indian affairs to look into this as we do and harken to our complaints to our welfare.

Mr. McDonald also told us we could not secure the service of another Indian teacher who would be as well suited as Mr. Elias. Allow us to say we can find one who will teach the proper method and thereby assure success it leads us to believe that he wants to keep Mr. Elias as teacher in spite of the above mentioned complaint.

Hoping sincerely to hear from the
Dept at an early date.

Washburn

Yours Truly

Dear Sir:

In answer to your communication in the Toronto "Daily News," I beg to make application for the position of teacher at Shawanaga. I commenced teaching at the age of eighteen here in the county of Oxford, and taught seven years; then went to the University of Toronto where I took the degree of B.A. in 1855 and two years of M.A. in '56. I afterwards taught in the high school at Mitchell, Ont. After this I accepted a very remunerative position upon the staff of "Harper Weekly," travelling around the world as special correspondent upon the subject of transportation.

In 1894 I wrote a book "Canadian curse" at the University of Oxford and obtained...
The degree of Doctor of Civil Law.

Following this I was appointed upon the staff of St. Mary's (clergy) College at the City of Toronto—a position I held for ten years. Underposition forced me to learn English and return to my own country three years ago; there I recovered my normal health. Last year I accepted a position as teacher at the St. Peter's Academy in Manitoba, which I have resigned as the clergyman, Rev. Louis Lefebvre, with whom I lived, left the district and landed just for a suitable place to board. I was very acceptable to the pupils and parents and I fairly believe that I was doing good there but they have not a suitable house in connection with the school. It was getting & 60 annually there.

Now I am not compelled to take a position but if I can turn a short of another to appreciate the advantages which British-Indian settlement afford.
I was doing such work as I was expected of him subject to rent.

Of course it expects its actual residence is furnished so as to be habitable by the teacher, and that my salary would be paid monthly.

I am fifty-three years of age, weigh over two hundred pounds—my constitution but extremely build. Am away from school but never feel abroad.

I have good recommendations from the Carlyle but insufficient of this kind and from others, which I would furnish upon request. Awaiting your reply I am

Dear Mr. Ferrier;

I had conversation with Mr. Moore, Public School Inspector for this district today, re the attendance of the whites at the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

Mr. Dumont, one of the residents in close proximity to Shawanaga Reserve, and who is married to a member of the Shawanaga Band, was one of the members of the community in that section to interview me today for the children of their section, numbering six, to be allowed to attend the Shawanaga School starting September term.

The reason he called, he stated, was because a Mr. Wilson of the Provincial Department, for the Mother's Allowance Board, informed him that the Department had made arrangements for the white children of their district to attend the Shawanaga School. I thought it strange that if this was so, I had been told nothing about it. Mr. Wilson, who is a visitor at my place in Parry Sound when he is in town, was a guest at my house the other night with his wife and daughter, and in the course of his conversation he mentioned the same thing to me that he had told Dumont.

This Mr. Dumont had called on Mr. Moore and Mr. Moore did not know anything about it, and he thought it strange that Mr. Wilson should know of this arrangement made. In conversation with Mr. Moore Inspector, I told him that I was going to write you about the matter and he said that he did not know why these children could not go to the Shawanaga School, because it would be quite a few miles farther to the next school, and they could not go there in the winter time.
Mr. Moore is of the opinion that there will always be room for these white children in the Shawanaga School. Mr. Moore mentioned the fact of the reciprocity arrangement between himself and the Department, re the white children attending Indian Schools and Indian children attending the white schools, and incidentally he mentioned that at Depot Harbour there are fifteen Indian children attending the Public School. Some time ago, I got a list from the Rev. Felstead, who is secretary of the School Board at Depot Harbour, stating that there were fifteen children attending at that time. I told Mr. Felstead that the matter had been arranged between Mr. Moore and myself, and concurred in by his department, that so long as it did not interfere with the space in the School for the white children, his Department was willing to have the Indian children attend. I just don't remember when this was.

Mr. Moore would appreciate it very much and so would the Department of Education in Toronto if we could continue to carry on the way we have been doing in the matter of the reciprocity plan. We benefit to the extent that there are nine more Indian children at Depot Harbour than there are whites at Shawanaga.

Mr. Ferrier, I am merely stating the case, and I presume you will understand that I am not trying to dictate. The arrangement that has been working here has been found to be very satisfactory and the mixing of the whites with the Indians in Shawanaga school has been to the benefit of the children. Would you be good enough to let me know if the Department has been in communication with the Mothers Allowance Board in Toronto, in connection with this case. Both Mr. Moore and I think it strange that any arrangements would be made without us being notified. We think that Mr. Wilson has misunderstood the arrangements that were made to allow the white children to go to Shawanaga School until the end of the June term.
If I could sit down at your desk and explain the situation to you, I am sure you would understand Mr. Moore's thought in this matter and how, I, as Agent here am looked upon as being a tyrant by these people who are living on the borders of Shawanaga Reserve, whose children are so near to the school and who there is room for (Mr. Moore says so) but they are not allowed to attend.

When I came out of the Hospital and heard of the arrangements made, the first opportunity I had to take the matter up with Mrs. English I asked her if she was satisfied to teach in this school. She said she was. I asked her if she had found fault with the white children being there or complained to Mr. MacGookin. She said she did not. It would make things go along very smoothly here if the white children near Shawanaga were allowed to go to the school. There would be no hardship in them doing so, either to the children or to the teacher. Mr. Moore would like you to give this your serious consideration.

I told him that I was writing a private letter to you and he thought that that was good business. Then if it is necessary to write the Department a letter, we could both consider the matter before replying to a reply from you re this.

Your consideration re this matter at your very earliest will be very much appreciated.

Kind regards to yourself, your family and the staff.

Yours very truly,

I have your T-3252 of the 28th ultimo, with reference to the attendance of white children at the Shawanaga Indian Day School. In view of your recommendation, I telegraphed you today as follows:-

"Reference your letter twenty-eighth ultimo, Department has decided to continue former arrangements at Depot Harbour White and Shawanaga Indian Day School. Mrs. English being informed that seven white children may attend without fees."

I am writing to Mrs. English and also to the Department of Education, Toronto.

Your obedient servant,

A.-P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound,
Ont.
TORONTO, September 2nd, 1931.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of September 1st and to express appreciation of your arrangement to allow seven white children to attend the Shawanaga Indian Day School on the understanding that the Depot Harbour Public School will allow the Indian children to attend there without fee.

This arrangement is very satisfactory to this Department and a copy of this and of your letter are being forwarded to Inspector J.L. Moore of Parry Sound.

Yours sincerely,

V.K. Greer
Chief Inspector.

Russell T. Ferrier Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ontario.

VKG-KEB.
J.D. Sutherland, Esq.
Acting Supt. Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Sutherland,

Mr. J. L. Moore Inspector of Schools in this district, has made inquiry re Departmental letter of Sept 1st, 1931, 22-5-1, following telegram sent on Sept 1st. re white children attending the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

It appears that some of the local men in the Shawanaga District have been behind in paying up their taxes and there is a question as to the authority of the white children attending the Shawanaga Indian Day School. Mr. Moore would appreciate it very much if you would renew this authority in such a way that it would continue until further orders from the Department. You will note by looking up correspondence that this arrangement has been going on for some considerable time and that we have Indian children attending the Depot Harbour School about equivalent to the white children attending the Shawanaga School.

Mr. Moore is very desirous of having this thing settled satisfactorily by Departmental authority. You will note that your Department has been in communication with the Department of Education in Toronto about this matter and I would suggest that the Department of Education in Toronto be notified to the effect that this arrangement will be continued until further orders.
Your earnest consideration will be very much appreciated by Mr. Moore and myself. Please reply officially by return mail if possible.

I take this opportunity of thanking you for your co-operation and help in my receiving the cheque to pay the men who were painting the schools at Moose Point and Magnetawan Reserves.

When I arrived home, on going through my correspondence, I looked for the cheque for the Indians who were painting the School at Gibson Reserve, but there was no cheque here. I intended going today to Gibson to pay these men, but as the cheque had not come, I could not go. I would appreciate it very much if the cheque for this work could be sent forward at your earliest.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

JMD/EK.

Agent.

P.S. I wired yesterday asking for the Cheque it was Indians who did the work, but it has not been sent forward since I wired please rush
Ottawa, September 12, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to the attendance of white children at the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

As you were informed by official letter of September first, 1931, the Department approves of the attendance of the white children, on the understanding that the Indian children can attend the Depot Harbour Public School, without fee. The Chief Inspector, Department of Education, Toronto, agreed to this arrangement and it is not considered necessary to have his further confirmation. The arrangement which was made for the attendance of the white children at Shawanaga is to be continued until further notice. You may so inform both the Public School Inspector and the teacher of the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

Cheques, in favour of the Indians who performed the labour in connection with the painting of the Gibson Indian Day School, went forward on the 9th instant.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

John M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Sir,

Ottawa, July 30th, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, informing the Department that Mrs. English, teacher of the Shawanaga Indian Day School, has not received her cheque for salary for the June quarter, last.

In reply I beg to say that cheques have been sent Mrs. English addressed to Shawanaga, Ont., as follows:

Cheque No. 2564 - $150 - sent July 7th,
2602 - 25 -

Mrs. English should apply at the post office at Shawanaga, and if they have not been received, the Department should be informed in order that they can be traced.

Your obedient servant,

Chief Henry Atkeylong

Note.

The Windows Sash in this School house are in very poor condition they have been patched and repaired so much by amateurs such as teachers and willing Indians. I can procure the Sash for $3.40 for the four Windows from the Parry Sound Lumber Co. Adam Paris who is plastering and whitewashing the School would do the priming and glazing at a small remuneration if he has the tools and one paint.

I beg to say that owing to the School house being in the centre of the Village playground and the young men meet and play foot ball in front and around the School in the evenings. I suggested to your Department some time ago that shutters be placed on the School Windows for protection during the Holidays or when there is no teacher in charge. My suggestion did not meet the approval. I hope for it is among the School children that the Windows are get broken.

D. Hillard

INSTRUCTIONS To Set SLATE BLACK-
BOARDS In SCHOOL ROOM

Observe carefully the marks upon the crates so as to get
the right boards for the spaces and room intended.

Carefully remove the side strips from the crates.

The crates should be kept nearly upright slightly leaning
to prevent boards from falling out when end strips are
loosened.

Observe the marks on the back of each board and as they
are taken from the crates convey them at once to the space
intended.

When the boards are thus arranged see that the bottom
strip which is to support the blackboards, has been firmly
set and perfectly square; if this strip is not square it must be
made so otherwise boards will require blocking on the bot-
tom.

Begin by setting end board (either right or left one), being
careful to set the part of the board marked on the right
place; this will bring the jointed end to meet the jointed end
of the next board.

Fasten the top moulding at the beginning end of the board
slightly above the next board marked, to meet the jointed
end of board already fixed to within about one-fourth of an
inch—not close up against. Observe how thick block should
be at the middle part of each board to bring them even; care-
fully place those blocks firmly, using a wire nail if neces-
sary.

Place the second board in position but do not bring it ad-
jacent the first by at least one-eighth of an inch; fasten firm-
ly by placing moulding of first board and then carefully
push the second board against the first by using a small
block of soft wood at the bottom corner of the second board.
See illustration.

ILLUSTRATION

| Top Moulding | Top | Top | Top |
|--------------|-----|-----|-----|
| SPACE        | 3rd Board | 2nd Board | 1st Board |

Bottom Strip Wainscoting

Proceed in this manner to set each board until the space is
completed.

If the surface of two boards are not perfectly flush at joints
on account of one board being slightly heavier, or blocks not
exact, they can be evened by a drawing knife or hone stone.

If for any reason it becomes necessary to cut off an end of
a board to make it fit properly, make a small cut, cut
gross about one eighth of an inch from the mark until board
is cut; the edge can then be rejoined by using a coarse and
fine file in succession.

It is sometimes found that the bottom strip upon which the
boards rest is not square and level, and the joints of the
boards are thus thrown considerably out of plumb; this can
be remedied by placing a small block under the end of the
board to raise it enough to bring the two jointed ends in line
again.

We assert without fear of successful contradiction, that SOLID SLATE BLACKBOARDS manufactured from our BIG BED SLATE, and Hand Shaved as we finish them, are more satisfactory to use in the School Room or elsewhere, last longer, are cheaper by one-half in the long run than any Composition, or any other Blackboard material out on the market.

THE QUARRYING AND FINISHING

of SLATE BLACKBOARDS is a most interesting process to those who have never seen slate worked.

Slate Rock for Blackboards is first cut out of the Quarry in large blocks, hoisted out by Steam Hoists, placed on cars, and conveyed to the Factory, where the block is transferred to one of the large Steam Saws, and cut as large a size as will permit, we will say 4x6 feet. It is then turned over to the "Splitter", who, with hammer and chisel, splits the block up into Slabs of the required thickness for Blackboards, (a full 3/8 of an inch). The splitting of blocks of this dimension must be very true, and indeed in our rock it is always so.

The pieces after being split are placed on the Rubbing Bed, and rubbed until the surface is perfectly smooth, and after which they are placed on the Shaving Table, and the entire surface is carefully and thoroughly shaved with a knife, by hand, until it has a surface smooth as a mirror.

The Board is then jointed at such ends as are to be joined to other boards, so as to make a perfect joint, after which they are properly crated and ready for shipment.

ORDERS

Should state the width required, and the exact length of space where boards are required. Where the space is longer than we can make a single board, we make two or more with perfectly true joints. The widths carried in stock are 3 feet, 3 feet 6 inches and 4 feet, although we will make other width boards when ordered. It is always understood that boards are to be finished on one side only, unless specially specified that both sides are to be finished, for which double faced boards we make extra charges.

TERMS

To responsible parties, or those having a satisfactory rating with the commercial agencies, or who can furnish acceptable references, we will extend credit for 30 days; otherwise we require at least one-half the amount of invoice paid when order is placed, or before shipment is forwarded, and balance on arrival at destination.

SHIPMENTS ARE MADE

Direct from our quarry, the blackboards being carefully packed in crates, each piece being marked so that its proper place on the wall is readily ascertained.

We will guarantee all our boards to arrive at purchaser's freight station in good order, and will replace F. O. B. Quarry Station, any blackboard broken in transit, providing a written certificate of such breakage is furnished us, signed by the freight agent at receiving point, and setting forth size of board or boards broken. No breakage claim can receive consideration without such certificate which may consist of memoranda of size or sizes of boards broken written across face of freight bill and signed by the freight agent. This written evidence we must have as a basis of claim against Transportation Company. We seldom find it necessary to do this as our boards stand ordinary handling with smaller danger of breakage. When requested we will furnish in addition to prices at Quarry Station, the cost of transportation to destination.

By carefully following the instructions on the next page anyone not accustomed to working and handling slate may set the blackboards in a building and make a neat job, as well as prevent chipping the jointed edges, which is possible if boards are moved in and out of spaces when joints are tight against each other. If it becomes necessary to take a board out after it is in place see that it is not touching the next board at joint.

Dear Sir,

Cheque #281 from your Department in connection with the Globe Printing Co., as alleged payment for advertising for a teacher for Shawanaga School. Sir,

The Public School Inspector, Mr. J. L. Moore, in a report on his recent inspection of the Shawanaga Indian Day School, states that the school building is far too small for the present attendance. He also states that there is a number of white children in attendance, and suggested that arrangements be made with the Ontario Department of Education towards the cost of providing suitable accommodation for the white and Indian children.

This Department is not responsible for the education of white children and if, owing to their attendance, there is not classroom accommodation for the Indian children on the Reserve, the teacher will have to discontinue allowing the white children to attend.

I will be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter, stating the number of Indian children of school age on the Reserve, the classroom accommodation provided and also the number of white children who have been attending, and if you consider there is not sufficient accommodation for the Indian children, you should notify the parents of the white children who have been attending that we cannot provide for their further attendance.

Sir,

I beg to state that after a careful survey, and consultation with the teacher, chief and councilmen of the Shawanaga band, I find that the present school is too small.

In my forecast of the requirements of this school in April 14th, I was hopeful that by placing three more desks in the building, we might get along for another year. I find that even now the school is crowded when all the children attend.

The expectations are that when school takes up in September that II new pupils will be on the roll. To meet the requirements I would recommend that an addition be built to the rear of the building 14 by 16, as the ceiling of the present school is too low. I would recommend that it be raised and instead of being —— I would have it —— giving more air space at very little cost.

This building is an old one, but with the improvement and addition, I propose doing with the Department's consent, it would serve to good purpose for the next 20 years.

I have made a rough estimate of the cost of addition and improvements at $1800.00. All labour can be found on the Reserve.

There is an Indian, Adam Pawie, who, I am told, can do the work.

There is a little plastering to be done to the teacher's house, and it should be painted outside to preserve it, and inside to make it look clean and attractive.

This matter should be taken up right away, if the work is to be started when school closes at the end of the term June 30th.

The teacher's house should be fixed inside before she goes on her holidays.

Please give this your earnest consideration.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Acknowledging receipt of yours of June 5th, I have to report that I have been to Shawanaga and measured the school building, the size of which is 26 ft. by 20 ft., and the height is 10 ft.

The addition could be built cheaper by putting it on the front of the building. The addition is 14 ft. by 20 ft.

It will be necessary to have a new floor put into the old section as well as the new.

The present building is on a cement foundation, and of course the extension would have to be carried on a cement foundation 2 ft. 6 in. in height.

There are no cleak-rooms in the present building, and I am allowing for cleak-rooms in the addition.

There will have to be a new platform and perhaps built in the improvements, and there must also be a new wood shed, as the one in use is rotten, what there is of it.

Both outside toilets are in the same condition as the wood shed.

It will be necessary to fill in all around the school, as in Spring and Fall, the school is surrounded with water, on one side for 20 ft.

The heating can be done by box stove, same as at present.

The Band asked that the work be done by their own men, day labour. I have talked the matter over with Adam Pawis, and he seems to me to be quite capable of looking after the rest of the workmen.

I have made arrangements with the Chief, Wesley Jacobs, to keep the time. The wages asked for are 45 cents per hour. The band govern the wages by what is paid in Parry Sound, and Depot Harbour. The men on freight, at Depot, get 46 cents per hour.

I followed the late agent's estimate in the fixing of the school at Lower French, and found him away out in his estimate, and in his idea of what was required to make the building suitable for a school.

When I said $1800.00, that was a rough estimate of what was required for the school improvements; and I had in mind, single desks, which are surely required. The desks at present are double desks, and are not conducive to the health of the children. I am told that they are about five years old, and I would strongly recommend that single desks be installed.

PROPOSED BUILDING
The present school building on the Shawanaga Reserve is too small to accommodate the number of children of school age on the Reserve. Requests have been made from time to time to enlarge the building by the erection of an addition. The Band in Council have passed a resolution that sufficient money to pay for the erection of the addition, raising the ceiling of the old building, and for the erection of toilets and a woodshed, be taken from the capital at the credit of the Band in Trust Fund Account #34. The present building is 26' x 20', on a cement foundation, and it is proposed to build an addition 14' x 20' on the front, put new flooring in the old building and raise the ceiling. This enlargement will provide ample accommodation for the children, there being 40 children of school age. The present enrolment is 52, which overcrowds the building.

It is proposed to do the work of erecting the addition, etc., by Indian day labour, under the foremanship of Adam Pawis, an Indian who is a competent carpenter, and proper time sheets will be kept for the labour employed. Mr. Agent Daly will supervise the work and see that it is performed satisfactorily. The cost of the addition, repairs to present building and the erection of toilets and a woodshed the Agent estimates to be about $1400, and he will endeavour to make it slightly less, if possible.

If you approve of this work being carried out during the coming summer, it will be necessary to obtain an Order in Council setting aside sufficient funds for the purpose. The amount of capital at the credit of the Band is $8,890.04. I would recommend, in the interests of the Band and as the work would be in the nature of a permanent improvement, that it be carried out during the coming summer.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th ultimo, regarding the building of an addition and the alterations required to the old school building at the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to inform you that an Order in Council has been obtained, which authorizes the expenditure of the sum of $1400, from the capital at the credit of the Shawanaga Band, for the purpose of carrying out this work. A new sodhouse should be erected, and both outside toilets should be repaired and put in good condition or new ones should be erected. The ground around the school should be filled in and levelled off, in order to prevent water from lying around the building in the spring and fall.

All the labour required in the building of the addition and in making the above repairs should be carried out by day labour, under the charge of a competent foreman. MEMORANDUM

April 27th, 1926.

Mr. MacKenzie,

With reference to the last paragraph in the resolution of the Council of the Shawanaga Band, relative to the disposal of any lumber that was left over after the repairs were made to the school building during the summer of 1923, I beg to say that we have no information in the matter.

The Band in Council authorized an expenditure of $1400 from the capital at their credit for the purpose of building an addition and making certain alterations to the school building at Shawanaga. This was approved by Order in Council of the 16th of July, 1923, (P.C. 95-1308) and Mr. Agent Daly was authorized to undertake the work by day labour - Indians being employed in the work, under the charge of a competent carpenter. The total expenditure was $1463.11. The Agent purchased all the lumber and other materials required, forwarding accounts in the usual manner, also time sheets for the labour employed. There is nothing on our files to show that any material was left over, and, if so, what disposition was made of same. If you consider it advisable, we could take this matter up with Mr. Agent Daly and obtain a report.

Sir:

Sir:

Following mine of December 24th, T-1609 re lighting of the Shawanaga School I have looked this situation over and have arranged for the loan of a stove for the remainder of the winter, through Mr. Kauffman, a lumberman who lives on the Reserve.

The lighting as mentioned in mine of Dec. 24th would be too expensive for this class of building.

I beg to submit the following report on

Shawanaga Day School:- requires painting inside and

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent inspection of the Shawanaga Indian Day School, states that the building requires painting inside and outside, as well as the closets and woodshed, and he recommends that this work be done next Summer.

The Inspector also states that at the present time six new window shades are required, also oil for the classroom floor and enamel for stove and stovepipes. You may arrange for the purchase and installation of the six window shades, also for the quantity of oil required for the classroom floors and enamel for the stove and stovepipes. There is no well at this school. Water for drinking and household purposes has to be carried from a creek about a quarter of a mile distant. I made enquiries and found that there are several drilled wells in the vicinity where water was found in abundant quantities at a depth of 20 feet. As soon as funds are available, I would recommend that a well be drilled on the school lot. The school buildings and residence are in very fair condition. Ottawa, June 22, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who visited the Shawanaga Indian Day School in April, last, recommends that a well be drilled on the school lot. He states that at the present time there is no well at this school and that water for drinking and household purposes has to be carried from a creek about a quarter of a mile distant. The Inspector states that there are several drilled wells in the vicinity where water was found in abundant quantities at a depth of 20'.

I have to request that you will make the necessary arrangements to have a well drilled on a suitable location on the school lot this present summer. Indian labour should be used as far as possible and all costs kept to the lowest point. You may also arrange for the purchase of a suitable pump, and the piping required, and a proper cover should be placed on the well. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have the well drilled and a pump, etc., installed at the lowest possible cost. When the work is completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I have to report that when at Shawanaga paying Fall payment, my attention was drawn to the condition of the belfry and the platform of the school, and also to the lack of doors on the toilets.

The belfry on the school is a danger and is liable to topple over any time, and the platform is very much in need of repair and a danger to the children going out and in the school. I would therefore recommend that sufficient lumber, nails, spikes, strap hinges, and hasps to make two doors for the toilets and lumber to repair the platform and belfry be purchased. The material and two days work by one man, would be sufficient to cover these repairs. I do not think it would exceed $15.00.

I would recommend that this work be done right away because of the danger of the belfry and platform.

The consideration of the Department by return mail will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Sir;

Replying to yours of June 5th, 22-3-2
22-5-5 and 22-6-5, re painting of schools,- The
Department asks how I would advise that this work
should be done.

From experience I find that I cannot get a
job that would be tradesmanlike done by the Indians,
so I have got in touch with a painter who has been
doing work for myself here, and got him to go out
and look at the Shawanaga School. He will do the
Shawanaga School for the price quoted, $230.00, two
coat job and would employ an Indian of the Band while
doing the work.

Sir;

Replying to yours of July 15th, 22-5-5m re the painting of the Shawanage Indian Day School, teacher's cottage, woodshed, and two toilets, also painting of the Lower French Indian Day School, teachers house, woodshed and two toilets, this work has been completed and the painter is now engaged in painting the Parry Island School.

I am well pleased with the work done and have found Mr. Stewart very satisfactory in this way, that owing to the schools being so long neglected it should have really been a three coat job, and where the work was not quite satisfactory with a two coat job, Mr. Stewart gave it another coat. Mr. Stewart has worked very hard and has certainly tried to do the work satisfactorily and for a two coat job I am satisfied that it will last for a year or two.

The cheque should be made out to Mrs. Fritsche as all the bills are charged to her. The paint, oils, etc., were purchased from McKinley Hardware Company. There was Indian labour employed at both schools and there will be Indian labour employed at the Parry Island School.

I am enclosing a bill sent by Mr. Stewart as to the time. Mrs. Fritsche is depending on me to make the division of the cheque so that each one will be paid according to the work done. In the case of the Lower French school as this job cost more money, Mr. Stewart advised me that it would not pay him to take the job unless he took an experienced helper with him. I knew this, so I agreed that he should do so. There were three men working at the Lower French School.
Please note that I have stated that Mrs. Fritsche is charged with this, and as she has the contract, I would respectfully request that the Department make out a cheque to Mrs. Fritsche and I have promised to help her make the division of it.

I am satisfied with the job done, and would strongly advise that these schools do not be left so long without paint in the future.

As all parties are in need of the money, I would appreciate it if the two cheques would be sent forward at the earliest opportunity.

as sent forward by William Beatty Co. and for
Joseph Pawis, and the bill enclosed would be
paid as soon as possible.

Re the shingling of the teacher's house
(not painting) and the painting of the interior
of the Shawanaga Indian Day School, I am having
a man go up there this week to give an estimate
of the cost. As soon as I get this I will send it
forward to the Department.
I would appreciate it if this school could be painted in the interior as both Inspector McGooking and Dr. McGill can vouch for the fact that the school is in a dirty condition and very much in need of painting.

I will likely have the estimate of the cost of shingling the teachers house and painting the interior of the school by the beginning of the week.

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

JMD/EK.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.,

Sir;

Yours of June 23rd 22-5-5 received stating that you regret that owing to lack of funds it is not possible to permit the painting of the interior of the Shawanega Indian Day School this year.

I regret this very much and would again urge on the Department that if there is any possible way that this work be done because we can never get it done any cheaper than we can now. What I mean by that is we cannot get it done so cheaply and so well.

I am notifying Mr. Claimont to go ahead with the work at the prices quoted, $96.75

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

JMD/EK.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 28th instant, with reference to the painting of the interior of the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

Before writing official letter of the 23rd instant, the Department gave very careful consideration to your recommendation that the interior of this school be painted. As you were informed in that letter, it is not possible to authorize the painting this year owing to lack of funds.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Secretary,
Department Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.,

Sir;

Enclosed please find bill for $4.00 in favour of Joseph Fawis for washing the ceiling and walls, and scrubbing the floor of the Shawanaga Indian Day School.

You may remember that I persistently made requisition for the painting of the inside of this school, but the Department did not have any money available for this purpose. The school was so filthy that I had to make some arrangements to improve it, so I got the caretaker to arrange to have two of the women of the Band wash the ceiling and walls and also scrub the floor. He paid the women $2.00 each.

This I consider a very good bargain and it puts the school in a sanitary condition until we will be able to get the requisition through on the March accounts for the painting of the interior of the school.

Would the Department be good enough to approve of my actions in this matter. Dr. McGill and Mr. McGookin will remember the filthy condition of the school.

The consideration of the Department at their very earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I am enclosing estimates of repairs necessary to the various schools in this Agency. Some of these estimates may appear high but the fact is that various repairs which were put off during the war years have accumulated.

The largest amount is for the Gibson Day School, the bulk of which is for fencing the school grounds and the erection of two new toilets. Authority was granted last year for these toilets to the amount of $112.00. I was unable to proceed with the work last year due to both the shortage of material and labour. I propose, if possible, to have it done this summer but a review of the situation shows the costs to be considerably increased due to prices of both material and labour.

I would be glad to have these costs for the various schools passed if at all possible but should it not be possible to pass on the amounts requested because of non-inclusion in the estimates, you might indicate what amounts would be available for expenditure on the various schools and I will have as much as possible completed this year and the balance next year. Parry Sound, Ont.,
November 19, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario

Re: Shawanaga Day School.

It has been recommended to me by the teacher of the above school that the pupils be supplied with soup for midday lunches during the winter months. About 35 children would be affected and Mr. Morris, the teacher, advises me that they bring very poor lunches to school.

Mr. Morris was at one time teacher in the Caradoc Agency and he tells me that he used this system there very successfully.

I have obtained a price locally on canned soup of $3.84 per case and I estimate that five cases would cover the requirements for four months, December, January, February and March. If it is possible to make this grant, I would be pleased to have your recommendation as soon as possible.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 24, 1947.

Mr. Samuel Devlin, Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, the Department approves purchase of five cases of canned soup at $3.84 a case for mid day lunches for the children attending the Shawanaga Day School.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
